vectorData.altText: 8. Hemispheric cerebellar lesions cause disordered movement of ____________ ___________ musculature. (two words separated by one space)
That is incorrect. Click here      to learn the answer, then come back to try again.
Thatâ€™s right!  Lesions of the cerebellar hemisphere cause disordered movement of ipsilateral distal limb musculature.

The coordination and accuracy of skilled voluntary movements, particularly of the hand, is dependent on a comparison of anticipated movement to ongoing movement. 



The cerebellum is informed of anticipated or ongoing movement through the cerebropontocerebellar inputs (blue) received from the contralateral motor and premotor cortices. Pontocerebellar fibres make up the whole of the middle cerebellar peduncle. The portions of the cerebellum involved in this function are the lateral portions of the cerebellar hemispheres and their associated deep nuclei. 
Their output projects via the superior cerebellar peduncle to the contralateral motor cortex via the ventrolateral nucleus of the thalamus (red). Thus the cerebellum influences the ongoing output of motor cortex via the CST (green). 
Signs of lesions of i) lateral portions of the cerebellar hemisphere, ii) the middle cerebellar peduncle or iii) the superior cerebellar peduncle are disordered fine movement of ipsilateral distal limb muscles.
